The "Internet Tax Freedom Act Amendments Act of 2007" changes the moratorium on internet taxes to extend until 2014. States that currently tax internet access are grandfathered in. The Internet Tax Freedom Act is amended to define 'Internet access' for subsections (a) and (b) based on previous enactments. Exceptions apply until June 30, 2008, for taxes on Internet access related to telecommunications services. Exceptions to the Internet Tax Freedom Act apply until June 30, 2008, for taxes on Internet access related to telecommunications services, under specific conditions outlined in the law. The Internet Tax Freedom Act prohibits states from enforcing taxes on telecommunications services used by Internet access providers in a way that contradicts the law. No legislative conclusions can be drawn from this subsection or related amendments before June 30, 2008, regarding taxes exempted under specific conditions. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. Section 1105 of the Internet Tax Freedom Act is amended to clarify the definition of Internet access services, including the purchase, use, or sale of telecommunications to enable users to connect to the Internet. The definition of Internet access services under the Internet Tax Freedom Act is clarified to include enabling users to access content, information, or services offered over the Internet. This encompasses services like home pages, email, instant messaging, video clips, and personal electronic storage. Excluded are voice, audio, or video programming, and other chargeable products or services utilizing Internet protocol. The definition of Internet access services under the Internet Tax Freedom Act includes various online services like home pages, email, instant messaging, video clips, and personal electronic storage. Excluded are voice, audio, or video programming, and other chargeable products or services utilizing Internet protocol. The term 'telecommunications' is defined in the Communications Act of 1934 and includes communications services as defined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. A specific exception to the tax on Internet access excludes State taxes on commercial activity, gross receipts, taxable margin, or gross income. The tax legislation enacted between June 20, 2005, and November 1, 2007, or between January 1, 1932, and January 1, 1936, must meet specific criteria, including not being discriminatory towards providers of communication services, Internet access, or telecommunications. The legislation allows states to modify taxes on business activities covered by the law after November 1, 2007, as long as the changes do not significantly limit the scope of the tax. No conclusions about previous tax applications should be drawn from this provision. SEC. 5 of the Internet Tax Freedom Act is amended to include telecommunications and enable access to internet content. Section 1108 is removed. SEC. 6 addresses the sunset of grandfather provisions. SEC. 6 of the Internet Tax Freedom Act addresses the sunset of grandfather provisions, stating that certain states are exempt if they have repealed taxes on Internet access more than 24 months prior to the enactment of this provision.
